# Learning objectives

_"As a developer who is new to ValidMind, I want to learn how to generate model documentation, add my own tests, edit the content, and then submit my documentation for approval."_

## In this training module

:::: {.columns .f2}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### SESSION 1

Initialize the developer framework

Start the model development process

Edit model documentation

Collaborate with others
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### SESSION 2

Implement custom tests and integrate external test providers

View documentation activity

Finalize testing and documentation

Submit for approval
:::
::::

# Edit model documentation

## {.scrollable}

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="30%" .pr4 .f2}
Now that you have generated some documentation, edit it on ValidMind to add text and test-driven content blocks.

::: {.f5 .nt2}
(Scroll down for the full instructions.)
:::

<br>Try it yourself on the next page. {{< fa hand-point-right >}}
:::

::: {.column width="70%" .bl .pl4 .f3}
### Add content blocks

Content blocks provide sections that are part of your model documentation — you can always add more, as required, and fill them with text or test results.

1. Select a model by clicking on it or find your model by applying a filter or searching for it.

2. In the left sidebar that appears for your model, click **Documentation**.

3. Navigate to the **3. Correlations and Interactions** section. 

4. Hover the cursor after the Pearson Correlation Matrix content block until a horizontal dashed line with a {{< fa square-plus >}} button appears that indicates you can insert a new block:
   
   ![Screenshot showing the insert button for test-driven blocks](../guide/add-content-block.gif){width=90%}

4. Click {{< fa square-plus >}} and then select **Test-driven block**:

   - Select **Threshold Test** as the type. 
   - Select **High Pearson Correlation Vm Raw Dataset Test** as the metric.

   A preview of the threshold test gets shown:

   ![Screenshot showing the selected test result in the dialog](../notebooks/images/selecting-high-pearson-correlation-test.png)

5. Click **Insert block**.

After you have completed these steps, the new content block becomes a part of your model documentation. You will now see two individual results for the high-correlation test in the **3. Correlations and Interactions** section of the documentation. 

To finalize the documentation, you can also edit the description of the test result to explain the changes made to the raw data and the reasons behind them. For example:

![Screenshot showing description added to the new content block](../notebooks/images/high-pearson-correlation-block.png)

</form>
:::
